thread.title_full: One thing is clear after Nets camp: Brook Lopez can’t be stopped | New York Post

author: Tim Bontemps
title: One thing is clear after Nets camp: Brook Lopez can’t be stopped
text:
It’s always dangerous to take away too much from snippets of training camp practices, when everyone is fresh and optimistic for the season.
But the universal thought to come out of Duke University this week after the Nets spent five days there was that Brook Lopez couldn’t be stopped.
After getting a chance to spend the summer working on his game instead of rehabbing from injuries, Lopez looked to be in midseason form in scrimmages open to the media, and people in and around the team repeatedly said he was unguardable.
“My rhythm and touch, they [already] feel there,” Lopez said. “I’ve had to work back into it the past few years because I couldn’t do anything with basketball during the summer.
“It’s a great confidence builder. … It was great to get back and play with my boys in the summer. That helped a lot, too. I was out there playing freely, just getting out there and doing things I normally do, and that helped carry over.”
It’s no secret the Nets need Lopez to be an All-Star for them if they have any hope of reaching the playoffs for a fourth straight season. If training camp was any indication, it looks as if that’s at least a possibility.
Here are a few other takeaways from training camp:
Big Bargnani Andrea Bargnani may not have many fans in the tri-state area after his two-year stint with the Knicks, but don’t be shocked if he begins the season as the Nets’ first big man off the bench.
Lionel Hollins appears to be a fan of Bargnani, who the Nets coach said has been a “breath of fresh air” and can play alongside any of the team’s big men. That includes Lopez, who Bargnani played next to for long stretches of the portion of Friday’s scrimmaging that was open to the media. It’s a combination Hollins is interested in seeing in action.
“Offensively, those guys are very versatile and they give a lot of problems to the defense, because both can shoot, both can pass, and both can put the ball on the floor,” Hollins said. “I like those guys playing together at times.”
Whether the pairing will work defensively is another matter entirely, but Hollins appears committed to giving it a shot.
Starters set Although there was some thought during the summer that Joe Johnson could wind up coming off the bench this season, it appears the Nets have a starting group of Jarrett Jack, Johnson, Bojan Bogdanovic, Thaddeus Young and Lopez to begin with.
That lineup obviously could have some defensive issues — particularly on the wings, where neither Johnson nor Bogdanovic is a plus-defender — but it seems the Nets will give it a chance to begin with the option to put in a better defensive presence there (either Wayne Ellington, rookie Rondae Hollis-Jefferson or Markel Brown) if it doesn’t work.
Brown out Speaking of Brown, he has been forced to miss significant time for a second straight preseason after suffering a moderate left oblique strain Thursday. That will make it difficult for him to crack the rotation early on this season.
Outside of Lopez, the biggest strength for the 2015-16 Nets is wing depth, and with Johnson, Bogdanovic, Ellington and Hollis-Jefferson all likely locked into places ahead of him, it could be a while before Brown gets a chance at regular minutes once he gets healthy.
